characters: VIEW THROUGH THE BARS OF THE GATE
EXT. GARDEN NEAR WATER BASIN- DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wild landscape in the morning light. We hear cannons in the distance. TITLE: “1864, VIRGINIA. 3 YEARS INTO THE CIVIL WAR” The small figure of a young blonde girl comes into frame. MAIN TITLES begin in red script over the woods as we foll the girl, AMY, 12, carrying a basket. We follow her as she dips in and out of the light in the shady grove, picking mushrooms as she finds small pockets them. She wears braids and a faded prim cotton dress of t era and sings a song to herself. The SOUND OF BATTLE increases in the near distance. SMOKE drifts over a shady glade, surrounded by trees and high bushes. Close on Amy’s freckled face; she shudders at the SOUND o loud CANNON, and bravely continues, adding mushrooms to h basket. She stops at a little shady patch of mushrooms, and as sh picks them, she comes across a SOLDIER’S BOOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow the boot up legs, and to the body of a man -- a WOUNDED SOLDIER, in a dirty, blood-stained Union uniform. Amy carefully leans in to take a closer look at his soot- covered face with a beard. Suddenly his eyes open -- she jumps back with a scream. The soldier looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Are you frightened?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: No... Yes. He looks at the young girl. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So am I. Amy moves in closer.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Can you move at all? He struggles to lean up a little on one arm.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I‘ll try, if there’s some place to go.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: The Farnsworth school is just on the other side of the woods. The Miss Martha Farnsworth Seminary for Young Ladies. He thinks about this.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Any men about?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: No men, just four other students, a teacher, and Miss Farnsworth. The slaves left. I can’t say you’ll be welcome as a Yankee, but it will be better than here.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: True enough. I’11 accept your invitation, can you help me up? Amy struggles to help him up.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you hold on just a bit, while I get my breath?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, sir. She uses all her strength to support his weight.

dialogues.speaker: AMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're a lot heavier than my brother. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where’s he now?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: He got killed in Tennessee.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: That wasn’t none of us, I was never in Tennessee. Now upright, he smiles at her in gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Amelia Dabney.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Mine’s McBurney... Corporal John McBurney.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Pleased to make your acquaintance Corporal. They start off slowly. The leg of his torn uniform is covered in blood. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're, off to where was it now?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Miss Farnsworth’s Seminary for Young Ladies.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: With only five students?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: The other girls have gone home, but Miss Martha kept it open. It was mainly we didn’t have anywhere else to go. They slowly make their way through the brush.

dialogues.speaker: AMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My home is Georgia, and my mother thought it would be better if I stayed up here in Virginia for a while... what with your General Sherman down there so close to Atlanta and all... Smoke rises behind them and cannons BOOM.

dialogues.speaker: AMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you run away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow them as they slowly make their way into the distance of the Southern landscape.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I’m with the Sixty-Sixth out of New York...We were hit and I fell and everything began to blaze...

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Do you want to go back? I can show you the way? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now. Maybe later when my leg stops bleedin’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A WROUGHT IRON SIGN: “THE FARNSWORTH SEMINARY FO YOUNG LADIES” Through the gates, a neglected-looking Southern mansion stands amongst dry plants and weeds. Nothing else in sigh Smoke rises in the distance. Amy and McBurney approach the gates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A class is in session. In a large living room that has been converted into a classroom, EDWINA, a tightly-wound, delicate beauty in he late-twenties, instructs a class of girls. She stands straight, with her high shirt collar buttoned the top and her hair pulled back primly. She looks confin in her tight, proper clothing. Edwina speaks in a gentle, well-bred manner and soft voic as she makes herself an example of a Southern lady to her students. There are four girls listening: ALICIA, 17, a bored, pretty blonde with long hair stares Her bodice slightly open, she fans herself with a noteboo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a fly buzzing in the corner. Alicia watches it. JANE, a prim 16-year-old with freckles, sits next to her carefully following along. Next to them is EMILY, a practical 15-year-old. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their faces are pink and dewy in the heat of the room, a they are all dressed in plain, long dresses of the period faded after being washed and mended many times. Some of t are half-dressed in petticoats. There is a blackboard propped up with a sentence in Frenc written on it.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: Le Mari de Marie est ici a Paris aujourd'hui. The girls repeat after her in unison. Alicia is pouty as she has better things to be doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of a BELL ringing breaks the silence of the hot day. In the bright sun, a woman with a large sun hat turns to reveal: MISS MARTHA FARNSWORTH, 40’s, a pale, worn, South beauty. With elegant posture, she looks like a lady, not accustom work outside in the kitchen garden. She turns to MARIE, a haired 12-year-old who is helping beside her. The BELL RINGS AGAIN, and Miss Martha lifts her skirt hem and rushes to the gate, followed by Marie.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Can’t be the patrol, they were just here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martha and Marie rush to the front gate. A VOICE calls out from a window above.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Amy and somebody’s there! The BELL clangs again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help! Miss Martha! Miss Farnsworth swiftly moves to Amy who is halfway up th walk to the large house. McBurney lies on the ground in front of her. The other girls rush out to them. Miss Martha’s hat has fallen behind her, her hair is swep off her face. Jane leans in to get a better look at the stranger.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Is he dead? Miss Martha checks his pulse.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Not yet. She turns to Amy.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sternly) How'd he get here?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: The woods were burning, I couldn’t leave him there to die. The girls all gather around him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: You know you’re not supposed to go that far! She looks at McBurney laying on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: We'll get him to the porch for now. You can all help, Edwina take his legs...

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss Martha. The girls surround McBurney. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McBurney opens his eyes, and looks up at: THE BACK-LIT GROUP OF CURIOUS, FLUSHED-FACED GIRLS, looki down on him. Their hair ranging from sandy blonde to chestnut brown. With a weak smile -- is he dreaming? -- he turns his head little to see: Miss Martha glaring down at him severely.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Sixty-Sixth New York, ma’am, and your grateful prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: A real blue belly! WIDER on the group as they lift his dead weight. Standing tall and efficient, Miss Martha helps the younge girls where his body is dropping. They start to make thei way toward the porch.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispers) You know they rape every Southern woman they come across...

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Stop that nonsense, Jane!

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: (in awe, staring down at him) You wouldn’t know from his face that he was a Yankee, would you?

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Run ahead, Amy, and open the door for us. And then you come right back here and tie that blue rag on the gate...

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: (maliciously, she bends down to inform McBurney) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blue rag’s so the patrol will know we’ve captured a live Yankee... McBurney’s eyes open briefly, he looks with pain and fear Alicia looks down at him through her hair, with a haughty look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group reaches the porch. We SEE the beautiful facade the house with the great columns rising behind them. They struggle to get McBurney up the steps. Miss Martha nods. She braces her back against a column as they set him down.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Is he breathing?

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you call out before, Emily? You must have seen them crossing the fields!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry Miss Martha. I forgot it was my turn to look out.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Someday you’ll forget and it’1l be Union scroungers in our garden! That’s how we lost most of our chickens. The girls cluster around him, fascinated. MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) Marie, you get up and look if you can see any of our soldiers. Marie reluctantly leaves them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: We ought to wash his wound.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: And sew it up. Amy -- didn’t I tell you to go tie that blue rag on the gate for the patrol? Amy reluctantly starts to go.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Couldn’t we wait a bit?

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: After all the blood he’s lost, he'd die if he went now. The girls look at Miss Martha.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Wouldn’t it be the Christian thing to do? She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Yes, and you’re quite right, Edwina, he’d never make it. We'll wait until he’s in shape to be taken away. Emily, put some water on to boil. Jane, Alicia, find any cloth we can spare and bring it to the music room. Miss Martha and the others use all their strength to brin him inside. The door of the mansion closes behind them. We hear the roar of BATTLE in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soft light comes in through the sheer curtains. A shrouded harp and harpsichord stand in the corner of th music room with a few music stands and gold chairs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Family portraits hang on the walls from another time, whe concerts were held. There are faded linens and other remnants from the mansion’s former glory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martha’s steady hands with shears as she cuts the fa of the pants of McBurney’s uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Torn pants fall on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: She sees his nakedness -- then looks away, composing hers to her ladylike ways. She covers him with a piece of line McBurney lies on a pale day bed, unconscious and pale und his thick beard. Beads of sweat form on his forehead. His hands are bandaged and he is naked, other than a clot across his lap. Edwina carefully puts a soft pillow under his head.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I need more cloth please, Edwina. Anything you can find.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss Martha. Miss Martha is leaning forward, stitching his wound. A strand of her pinned-back hair has fallen forward in he work; she pushes it back, in concentration. Her brow perspires. Edwina moves a pot of water, as she goes for the cloth. McBurney’s belt is draped over a chair.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: There’s enough metal in there to shoe a horse... I think I got most of it. Edwina with flushed cheeks, looks down on McBurney’s hand face. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwina’s hands dip a cloth into a bowl of water. She wrin it out -- water drips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwina’s hands wipe the cloth over McBurney’s forehead. A slight moan from McBurney, still unconscious. CLOSE on her hands and cloth wiping soot off of his face. Water drips down his face, on to his scruffy beard, down smooth chest. She carefully wipes his chest. Miss Martha finishes up her work. Edwina, on the verge of fainting, steadies herself with t back of a chair. MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) Edwina, please get more water and I’1l bathe him. I’m going to get him a clean nightshirt.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA, (SOFTLY)
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss Martha. Edwina follows Miss Martha to the door. Edwina glances back at McBurney. Miss Martha opens the door wide -- swiftly. In the doorway, the school girls all crowding around tryi to get a glimpse of the man, scatter backwards, caught.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I thought so!

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: (almost hopefully) Is he going to die? Miss Martha and Edwina come through the door. Miss Martha shuts it behind her.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Not today, I don’t think. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She locks the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The key turns in the lock and is left there. We hear the stiff metal turn.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Then what’1ll happen?

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: We'll turn him over to the patrol, of course. If by some miracle he lives through the night, which I doubt. In the meantime I don’t want anyone poking in here or lurking in the hall...

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: His name, in case you've wondered, is Corporal John McBurney.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I’m afraid he won't be here long enough - dead or alive - for his name to make any difference to us. She turns to Edwina. MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) There’s too much distraction for any more studying today.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: We have a lot of mending to do.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Good! To the sewing room, all of you! She claps her hands to shoo them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a girl’s hand carefully stitching a thin piece o cloth. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Careful, keep your stitches in a straight row. In an old salon, the girls sit around a table with Edwina Everything in the room feels faded. The table has small pieces of cloth, bits of old curtains tablecloths, and sewing supplies. They chat as they sew.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Jane, it’s the same for you as all of us, you don’t leave because there’s nowhere for you to go...

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: There is so! My father is with General Lee and if I so desired, soldiers would come escort me to him now.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: If anybody knew where that was.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: My mother wrote me from Charleston that the blockade is fearful. She says I probably eat better here than I would at home.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: You do.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: You should have never brought that Yankee here, Amy.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I agree. He’s probably a spy and will let the blue bellies in at night to raid our garden.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: I doubt that, Jane.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Miss Edwina, aren’t you afraid of that blue belly? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: No. And it is very bad manners to call him a blue belly. He has a name, Corporal John McBurney.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (dreamily) Johnny... The girls giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McBurney is passed out, as Miss Martha sits next to him w a bucket of water and pieces of cloth. Having volunteered before as a nurse, she keeps a professional posture, but it is clear that she hasn’t see man’s body in a long time. She pushes her hair back as she dips a cloth into the war water and cleans his arms carefully. Sunlight outlines hi body as she cleans his shoulders and chest. Then his legs Miss Martha takes a deep breath, and lifts the cloth cove him, as she moves the cloth to his hips and inner thighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls continue their sewing under Edwina’s guidance, the afternoon sun streams through the sheer curtains.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MISS MARTHA’S ROOM - DAY It’s late afternoon. Miss Martha goes to a basin and splashes water on her fac taking a moment to compose herself. She smooths her hair back in place. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her room is that of a lady of the time, with a delicate v on a fine dresser. Suddenly she’s interrupted by the sound of A LOUD BANG -- spoon hitting an iron pot O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McBurney opens his eyes -- alarmed. His head rests on an embroidered linen pillow case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martha rushes down to see Jane and Alicia.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: It’s our boys, Miss Martha. They’1l be passing our way. Alicia's bosom is pushed up in her tight bodice.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Can’t we go and greet them?

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Confederate soldiers? Alone?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I think, maybe they have some prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I don’t want them to see you girls. Go upstairs! They run upstairs. Miss Martha goes to the mirror in the foyer on her way ou She buttons her collar high and smooths her skirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small group of CONFEDERATE SOLDIERS march past the scho gate. They are battle-weary, in worn uniforms. Behind their wag Yankee prisoners march slowly along. Miss Martha opens the gate to greet them.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: What’s the news?

dialogues.speaker: CONFEDERATE SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Taking these Yanks to prison to die. A CONFEDERATE CAPTAIN rides up on his horse, bowing his h to Miss Martha as he dismounts. INT. GIRLS’ BEDROOM - DAY CLOSE on Amy, perched at the window; she looks down on th scene.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You think Miss Martha’s going to tell them about him? Alicia, Jane, and Marie pass a row of single beds with fa blankets and quilts and lean in around Amy, trying to see

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain, now standing, talks to Miss Martha at the ga She stands composed, like a lady, with a subtle tilt of h head, as if she was at the entrance of a ball.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: You all alone, ma‘am?

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Just a teacher and a few students. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Well, take care. Ma’am. Lot of these Yanks got separated from their outfits. They’re roaming these woods and they’re desperate.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Yes, Captain. I wonder if you might have a few cartridges you could spare.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: What good would that do you, ma’ am?

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: My father left his revolver, and I'd feel much safer knowing I might use it if needed. He nods in respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girls’ POV from the house.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: They see the Captain handing Miss Martha a small packet.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Is she telling him?! Jane looks over Amy’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: AMY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He’s giving her something?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Through moss-covered trees, we see the Captain and his gr start off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AMY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They’re leaving, she didn’t tell them! ! WIDE on Miss Martha as she strides toward the mansion. INT. MISS MARTHA’S ROOM- DUSK Close with Miss Martha as she opens a drawer and takes ou revolver. She loads a few cartridges into the gun, and puts it back shutting the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surrounded by mossy trees, Marie walks around on look-out the evening sun sets. We hear the sound of CICADAS and CRICKETS joining in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwina passes the music room to see the door open --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the low light, Edwina pauses to look through a space i the slightly open door. She sees Amy inside kneeling at the beside of a sleeping McBurney, whispering to him. Edwina shoots her a look.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: (trying to keep her voice down) What are you doing there! Amy looks over to her in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I was just telling him something private. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: Let him rest.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (whispers to McBurney) See you later. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy bids adieu to sleeping McBurney and heads out, stoppi at Edwina in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: AMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was just checking on him. I thought he might want some company. Edwina is stern with her.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: He’s not one of your wounded birds or beetles. Amy gives her a look and rushes out, as Edwina closes the door. McBurney watches her. Under her tight-laced primness, it seems like Edwina migh burst. The door shuts -- we hear the KEY turn the lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martha, standing tall in her high collar, reads from bible in the candlelight. The girls all sit in attendance. Edwina carefully follows along. Alicia goes up to Miss Martha and whispers to be excused.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Can you wait? Alicia shakes her head. MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) Alright, then. Edwina watches as Alicia slips off. MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) Does anyone wish to ask for special blessings? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: I pray that the Lord will see fit to restore the health of the wounded soldier. The girls lower their heads.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: We will pray for his return to health and for his early departure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on McBurney as he sleeps. We hear the sound of the KEY turning the lock. In the dark room, Alicia sneaks up close to his face. She touches his beard, and moves in close to him, getting good look at him. She leans in and lightly kisses his lips, then kisses him longer this time. With his eyes still closed, he seems to kiss her back. McBurney’s eyes open for a second, looking lost, as if in dream. Alicia looks at him, still breathing softly.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: (whispers) Good night, Corporal. Alicia sneaks off before she’s caught. McBurney watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slipping in with an innocent look on her face, Alicia rej the group in prayer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21a. Heads are lowered in the candlelight. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I ask God’s blessing on our armies, and the safe return of our boys. Edwina glances up from her bible at Alicia, knowing she i to something. Alicia gives her an innocent smile like -- what?! She sli back into her chair and bows her head with the others. Sh has a tiny secret smile on her lips. Edwina returns her head down in prayer.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: And we pray for those we have lost. May we all be kept from harm throughout this night. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: GIRLS
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls follow Edwina up the stairs, whispering. Miss Martha follows behind, to keep them together, holdin a candlestick in the dark stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: To your rooms, quietly girls. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birds chirp as the sun rises over the old mansion. A cannon fires in the distance. We SEE some SMOKE far off in the distance.  23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The birds continue as Amy opens the door and peeks in. McBurney winks at her as she approaches him. He is cleane up and wearing a linen man’s nightshirt.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Good morning. It is morning, I take? She nods.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: It’s about six.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I thought as much from the larks I heard singing.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Do you like birds?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Love them. Anything wild I love... wild and free.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I think they’re robins. I can show you some nests I collected?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: That would give me great pleasure. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I better go... Miss Martha's coming to fix your bandages and bring your breakfast. She slips off.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Okay, then. Thank you, darlin’ She smiles back at him as she leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen is busy with morning activity. Sun pours in through a window that looks out over the kit garden. A basket of greens and thick ceramic bowls sit on a side table. Heavy iron pots hang by the stove, where Emily tak a pot off. The girls eat porridge over the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: How’s the Yank doin’?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: He’s fine, much better...

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: How long is he going to stay in the music room?

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: Until he’s much better.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: But, how can I practice the harp with a dangerous enemy in the same room? The other girls are used to her complaining. Miss Martha sweeps into the busy kitchen. She is more put together than usual. She passes Edwina, who is wearing a special dress. She we a beautiful necklace on her pale floral dress. Miss Marth admires it. Edwina continues to shell beans.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Trés jolie. She gives her a loaded look, and then looks over at the o girls. Emily has earrings on and Alicia has a flower in h hair. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (cool amusement) Seems like the soldier being here is having an effect.... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy passes with her bowl. MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) Tell me, Miss Amy, did you find any mushrooms when you were out collecting soldiers?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I did, but only poisonous ones I think.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Let’s have a look later, shall we?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Yes, ma’am. With her dignified posture and rustling skirts, Miss Mart crosses frame, leaving them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun beams thru fresh linens being hung on a clothes l Edwina and Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McBurney looks up with a cheerful smile as Miss Martha enters. Some of the girls whisper and giggle as they peek in and to get a look at him.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: (to girls) Get on about your business, you have work and studies to do.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Shall we not have music here this morning?

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: No, we shall not. Please go to the library. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes the door on them. She goes over to check on her patient. MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) Good morning, Corporal. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I'm disrupting your place here.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Indeed you are. She sets to work checking his bandages; she is all busine She takes his hand and examines it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hand in hers. Miss Martha pauses a moment, looking at his manly hand. She continues to dress his wounds.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: You don’t mince words, ma’am. You speak right up, I like that.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Do you indeed? And do you think it makes a great difference to me whether you like it or not? He looks at her, enjoying the rally.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I’m sure my opinion means nothing at all to you, ma’am... I’m not looking for your praise.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Are you not. What are you looking for then?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Whatever you can spare me. You have given me plenty and I’m most appreciative. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Aren’t you afraid I’1l turn you over to our soldiers?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: No, I don’t think so. I don’t say you won’t do it, but very likely worse things could happen to me. I don’t relish the prospect of prison, but it’s better than being dead. And that’s what I would be if you hadn’t helped me. There is something lovable about him.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Not necessarily. Is your leg paining you?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Yes, some.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Well, I hear that numbness would be more grave. There’s brandy if you wish.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: That would be a pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: It isn’t being offered for your pleasure, only for your comfort.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Yes, ma’am. Miss Martha sits up straight.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I must remind you Corporal McBurney, that you are not our guest, but a most unwelcome visitor. We don’t propose to entertain you here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I wouldn't expect it ma’am.... though you'll find I’m easily amused. McBurney looks to see Alicia in the doorway -- with a fak innocent look on her face. She looks up through blond strands of hair. Miss Martha turns.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: What is it, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: I just wondered if there’s anything I can do to help? McBurney looks at Alicia. Martha notices, protectively. McBurney lies back. Miss Martha goes back to addressing Alicia.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: There is nothing you can do here. You have enough studies and other work to keep you well occupied.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: I only thought to help.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: That won’t be necessary. And Miss Alicia, you can tell the others this room is off limits.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Yes, ma’am. Alicia gives an insolent little curtsey, with a conspiratorial look to McBurney, she leaves.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: You can trust me in your place, ma’am. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I don’t know you.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: If you got to know me, I think you would.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: You won't be here that long. Miss Martha nods and picks up her skirts and makes her wa out.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Ma’ am?

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Yes Corporal?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I'd like a bit of soap anda razor if you have.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I’1ll see what I can find.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Thank you, ma’am. He smiles at her happily, like a schoolboy. Miss Martha leaves. McBurney lies back on his bed, marveling at his fortune t find himself in such a prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a hand practicing cursive - writing out a poem: ‘Never seek to tell thy love, Love that never told can be. For the gentle wind does move Silently, invisibly.’ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: Careful with your ‘E's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy sits in a large oak tree, looking out from its branch The days seem endless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily and Alicia hoe in the rows of the vegetable garden the hot sun. Alicia’s not cut out for this kind of work.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Are we almost done?!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Almost... this is the last row. Some CANNONS, less than before, are heard in the distance

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwina stands in the doorway, something in her hand. She takes a moment to smooth her hair, before entering. Small Marie slips past her, beating her into the room to McBurney.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, won’t you, Miss Edwina? I have some personal business here. Edwina watches as Marie brings a book to McBurney, marvel about what business a twelve-year-old would have here wit him. Edwina waits at the door, impatiently. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marie speaks in a low voice, keeping her conversation wit McBurney private.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wanted to bring this to you last night for fear that you might die before morning, but then I thought since you were unconscious, you wouldn’t be able to read it anyway.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: That’s very logical.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Are you Protestant?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I was baptized Catholic.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Well then, here’s a prayer book for you.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: I thought you might need to confess if you’re on the verge of death.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I think I can hold out a little longer. He smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m John Patrick McBurney.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you, sir. Marie curtseys and rushes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwina turns, blocking Marie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: Just a moment, Miss. Marie stops and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where do you think you’re going in my jade earrings? Marie gives her a cute smile.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Oh Miss Edwina, don’t be hateful. Everyone is dressing up today.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: Not in my jewelry, they’re not.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: I‘1ll give them back. And how beautiful you look this morning, you're all dressed up yourself.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: I am not.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: I haven't seen that beautiful necklace since last Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: Get to your work. Marie ducks and runs past her, laughing. Edwina pauses, embarrassed by her un-ladylike behavior. S starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Wait, don’t run off when you’ve just come. Edwina turns and sees McBurney lean up, across the room.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you want to see me about something? Edwina nods stiffly and enters.  33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwina stiffly glides over to McBurney’s bedside. She opens a white handkerchief and places a small bar of lavender soap, a razor, and a tortoiseshell comb on a tab next to McBurney with a pitcher of water on it. She freezes up, not knowing what to say.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. He reclines, trying to clean his black fingernails.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: They look as if you had been trying to dig a pit with them.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I was. In the battle, with all that iron flying overhead, my first thought was to bury myself.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: And when you couldn’t, you ran?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I did. I surely to God did. Edwina looks at him, his eyes smiling.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: It wasn’t very brave of you to run. She makes herself busy with some task, straightening up t table beside him.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Maybe not, but it was smart, I think.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: Because you’re alive?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: And now I’ve met you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don’t even know me.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I know your name... Miss Edwina Morrow.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: And what else have you been told about me?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Nothing besides your name. It’s a lovely name. She checks his bandages like a kind nurse.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: I hope the girls weren’t telling stories.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: What do you care what is said about you?

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: I don’t...I just didn’t want you to have the wrong impression. Edwina looks at him. McBurney smiles up at her warmly, his eyes sparkling. She moves again.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Then you do care what I think about you.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: You’re a stranger here, that’s all, and I don’t want you to be misled.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Well, perhaps you can set me off on the right foot and tell me about yourself. Where are you from, Miss Edwina Morrow? 34. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes this questioning. 35.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: My father’s home is Richmond, I left Savannah when I was quite young. We lived in several places for my father’s enterprises.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: And, are you waiting for your sweetheart to return when this war is over?

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: I have no one in the military. in, studying her. She’s uncomfortable with his

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: And how did you end up here?

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: Why are you so interested in me?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Because something tells me we're both out of place here. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘1l bet you're the independent sort who the others don’t know how to get close to, and then of course there are your looks.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: That doesn’t matter to me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: In all my travels, I’ve never come across a delicate beauty like yours. He stares at her, she turns away. He grabs her arm and pulls her closer to him.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell, me Miss Morrow, what’s your biggest wish, if you could have anything, what would it be?

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Anything. She is almost breathless, and gives in for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: To be taken far away from here. He looks into her eyes. She straightens up and composes herself, standing. She smooths her hair.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good day, Corporal.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: John. She looks at him and turns, taking a tray from the table glides out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwina braces herself against a wall, and after a heavy exhale, she composes herself and moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late afternoon. Jane and Marie get a pail of water from t pump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily is on lookout as the sun begins to set. She sings to herself.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. GIRLS’ ROOM - EVENING CLOSE on Amy as she feeds a little piece of lettuce to he pet TURTLE.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Here you go, Henry. She arranges an old box of her treasures, a smooth rock, small bird’s nest. She adds a brass button after showing Henry.

dialogues.speaker: AMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. McBurney gave me one of his buttons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We FOLLOW Amy, the last one to sit at the dinner table. She takes her seat and looks to Miss Martha to see if she be scolded. Miss Martha, an example of perfect posture, smiles at her She lowers her head. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: The eyes of all wait upon thee; and thou givest them their meat in due season. Thou openest thine hand, and satisfiest the desire of every living thing. Bless us and these thy gifts which we receive from thy bountiful goodness, through Jesus Christ, our Lord, Amen. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GIRLS, (IN UNISON)
dialogues.text: Amen. Miss Martha looks at them pleasantly as they start their meal.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: It has occurred to me that we might all reflect on the unexpected presence of Corporal McBurney in this house -- until his leg heals, of course. And we might discuss how we may practice compassion and what else we may learn from this. What does each of you think of this? Miss Martha looks around the table at the girls. MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) Miss Alicia, can you tell us how we may learn from his presence here? They all look to Alicia.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Well, maybe the sight of him will remind us there is something else in the world besides lessons.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: It seems to me that is all there should be for any young lady your age. If we learn our lessons properly when young, we can expect a calm and happy life when we are faced with the distractions of the world. N’est- ce-pas? She looks to Edwina like, ‘Isn’t this so?’ Edwina nods. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: With the presence of this hateful enemy, he will be a constant reminder to us that the war is still going on, and the sacrifices and prayers we must make.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: May I say, that any breath of fresh air from the outside world, I think is welcome to us all.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I heard he said he was a mercenary, so maybe he’s not even really the enemy.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: What’s a mercenary?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: It means he’s just paid by the army to fight, he’s not really fighting their cause.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Well, we don’t know about that.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: He seems to be a student of nature, so I expect to learn about foreign wildlife.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: He seems to be a sensitive person.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Does he?

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: I found him understanding.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Do you, indeed? You must share more of your findings with us, Edwina. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As dedicated Christians, let us ask the Corporal to join us in our evening prayer.  40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women join McBurney in the candlelit room. He is clean shaven and wearing a crisp shirt and trousers propped up on pillows on the settee.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Since our music lessons were suspended today in order to permit the Corporal to rest, why don’t we have a little music now -- if Corporal McBurney will not be too disturbed by a little divertisement?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Not at all, ma’am, I’m very fond of music.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Miss Jane?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Yes, ma’am. Jane begins playing the harpsichord.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Why, you play beautifully Miss Jane. She smiles, uncomfortable so close to this enemy.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Doesn't she.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: I can also play for you, Corporal.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I’m sure you can. Edwina gives Alicia a sharp look -- do you always have to such a slut? Alicia shrugs at Edwina. Jane starts to sing and before long they’re all singing a with McBurney joining in. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4l. Amy gives McBurney a smile. The room is full of smiles and merriment -- Edwina and McBurney share a warm glance. Alicia sneaks a sultry look -- until A LOUD KNOCK at the front door interrupts them. Jane stops her song.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Yankees?!

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Possibly not. It could be some of our own. LOUD KNOCKS hit the door below again. MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) Edwina, wait here with the girls and I'll go to the door. She looks at Edwina. MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) If it is Yankees or unruly soldiers of our own army, I will rap three times on this door. Then you will take the girls out to the woods behind the garden and stay there until I come for you. She starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: What about Corporal McBurney? McBurney looks as scared as the girls.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: He may remain where he is since he’s in no condition to leave. I’m going to get the gun. Be quiet in here, all of you. Miss Martha starts to go. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Can we cover him with something?

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Yes. Shh. She leaves. In silence, the girls lean against the door, trying to he something. We hear MUFFLED VOICES. The girls hold their breath.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MISS MARTHA’S ROOM - NIGHT CLOSE on Miss Martha’s hands taking the gun from her draw We hear banging on the door below 0O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martha hurries down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: LOOKING DOWN THE HALL
dialogues.text: Miss Martha talks at the open door. The music room door opens just a crack. The GIRLS’ POV watching Miss Martha, trying to see who sh talking to. Miss Martha steps aside and opens the door wider as two m enter the house. They quickly close the door and listen to the loud, heavy footsteps as the men walk down the hall. The steps grow closer and closer and then stop outside the music room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42a. The girls all stand completely silent and still holding t breath... The steps continue down the hall toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door slowly opens and Miss Martha comes in pale, but triumphant, holding the gun. She composes herself, out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: It’s all right. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls are relieved -- they can breathe again. MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) There are just two of them -- two cavalrymen of our own. They’re having something to eat in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: Why did they come?

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: To offer their assistance before the army leaves this vicinity. I haven't as yet mentioned Corporal McBurney. The girls look at each other and over to McBurney -- help on the settee. MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) I might ask them to take him with them.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: But he couldn’t ride without hurting his leg.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I could tell them about him and suggest since he’s wounded that they come back for him, but that could be weeks or months.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: They’1l probably insist on taking him right now, and who knows what’1l happen to him.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: They’11l likely shoot him and leave him along the road. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I could allow him to stay until he is recovered and then send him on his way alone.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: There is Christian charity to be considered.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (close to tears) You keep talking about him as if he were some old piece of baggage, and not a kind person who is in this room. Oh, please, Miss Martha.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: And there are the doubts if we can really consider him an enemy. They all look at Miss Martha. McBurney waits for his fate

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I will allow Corporal McBurney to remain until his leg heals. If one of you is opposed, I will tell the soldiers and let them decide what to do with him. She looks around at the girls. No hands are raised. MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) Well, then. She is relieved, and seems to remember the gun in her han (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) When the soldiers saw me with this, I believe they were more frightened than I was! They said nothing was more frightening than a startled woman with a gun. She laughs on her way out.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: May I accompany you Miss Martha, to say a few words of cheer to our men?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I'd like to come too.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: They seem decent enough, but there’s no need to put temptation in their way. Now get to bed. The girls file by on their way. Miss Martha turns to McBurney. MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) Would you care to join me for a brandy, Corporal?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cavalrymen ride off in the moonlight. The lights in the house go black. INT. GIRLS’ BEDROOM - NIGHT As the SOUND of the horses’ HOOVES fade, we hear an OWL outside their window. Amy, Jane, and Emily whisper from their beds in the dark room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I wonder how long he’1l stay.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Miss Martha seems to be warming up to him, and I believe he likes it here.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Oh, what would you know?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I've talked with him privately.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You think just because you found him, you have some special relationship...

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You're just jealous.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Shhh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martha sits across from McBurney in front of a fire the small parlor. They sip brandy in the warm glow of the fire. Miss Martha leans back, letting her guard down, relieved be with another adult for once.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: What a night.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: It must be tiring for you.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I can’t say it hasn’t been a struggle.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I admire your strength. She smiles in thoughtful appreciation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know it must be hard for you to be strong all the time for these girls, they’re lucky to have a woman like yourself to keep going for all of them.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I want to give them what they’1l need to survive in these times. It will be such a different world they’1l be going out into, I don’t think they realize.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: They can’t know what it’s like out there.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Sometimes I get so tired... I pray the end is near. It’s hard to find any sense in it, how much everyone has suffered.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Did you have someone before the war?

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Everyone has lost so much.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I was a coward to leave, but you don’t realize what battle really is until you've seen it.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: It must be devastating. He looks at her in appreciation of her kindness. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t have been there. I’d just come from Dublin, I had nothing. I took three hundred dollars to take a man’s place. 47A. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I see... We’ve all done things out of our character. We’1ll look to it that you make your way home. Thank you for your company. If you’ll excuse me, I must insist you rest. Miss Martha stands, her figure outlined by the fire.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Good evening, Corporal. She nods and walks out into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun floods in and birds chirp on a new day. McBurney -- clean-shaven and hair combed -- is standing, starting to walk carefully with the help of a cane, as Am his side watches. Miss Martha enters.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Look, Miss Martha! Miss Martha goes to McBurney.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Now lean on the cane and your good leg. Don’t put any weight on your bad leg.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Yes, ma’‘am.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I still wouldn’t rush nature to take her course, but if you want to take the risk of reinjuring your leg, feel free to do so. McBurney slips a little, and Miss Martha and Amy rush to him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) Steady, Corporal!

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Will you help me outside, Miss Amy?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Yes, of course Corporal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily and Alicia pass through. McBurney nods to them as h makes his way slowly. Alicia smiles at him coyly.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Ladies.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Good-day, Corporal. Miss Amy, it’s your turn in the kitchen garden.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I’m helping the corporal, as you can see.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Well, I’m sure we could relieve you.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Girls, that’s enough. I'’1l be the one to let you know whose work is needed, now go on your way. Emily and Alicia give Amy a bitchy look, and continue on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy helps McBurney as he slowly moves along. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49a, He looks out over the garden. Miss Martha stands in the doorway nearby. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Your roses need pruning... and those hedges are in terrible shape. The whole flower garden needs help, I’1l get to it tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Surtout pas. You’1l do nothing of the kind. It’s kind of you to offer but it has been neglected for some time, and it can remain that way a while longer.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Have you had much gardening experience, Corporal McBurney?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Oh yes, I did a good bit of it.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Well, if you really have a knack for gardening, you can make yourself welcome later in your convalescence. The English box hedge hasn't been trimmed properly for years now, and we have enough with keeping the kitchen garden going.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: It would be my pleasure, ma’am. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McBurney works in the garden in the hot sun, he looks ove Edwina passing. He stares at her. CLOSE on Edwina over by the mossy oaks with a basket of linens-- she feels his stare, and tilts her head, pretend to not notice him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McBurney prunes a hedge. CLOSE on McBurney working up a sweat as he sharpens old garden tools on a block of granite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He works a blade across the stone, as it sharpens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwina and Emily pick some vegetables in the kitchen gard McBurney stops to watch her. CLOSE on Edwina’s flushed face as she works in the garden she steals a glance at him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GARDEN NEAR WATER BASIN- DAY
dialogues.text: McBurney continues his work pruning the rose bushes and cutting away dead vines. He wipes the sweat from his forehead. Amy brings him a glass of water. He thanks her with a win and a smile. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy smiles. Amy beams. 52.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Miss Martha told me to return to my lessons but I told her all the things you need me to do.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m counting on you to keep my clumsy feet away from bird’s nests and my spade from decapitating friendly worms. That plus keep me company.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t tell anyone else, but I consider you my best friend in this place.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Of course I do, now hand me those shears, will you, my girl. They continue their work. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McBurney looks up to see Edwina watching him through a la curtain. McBurney splashes water on his face from a bucket to cool off. Water drips over him. His eyes meet Edwina’s and she turns away. Alicia and Emily wave to McBurney from nearby. He gives them a nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Amy passes to go inside, Emily and Alicia tug her brai

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: You better not be saying unkind things about us to the Corporal. Amy politely smiles.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Now, why would I ever do that? She continues on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McBurney rests on a bench by a great oak. Miss Martha comes over to him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Corporal, I wonder how your leg is?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: It twinges a bit now and then.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I would expect that. You may recall I was opposed to you walking on it so soon, however I can appreciate your need to be active. May I check?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Yes, ma’am. He sits on a bench, as Miss Martha checks the wound under bandages.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: The stitches seem to be holding and the wound is healing nicely.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: When do you think I’1l be recovered?

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Some may say you’re recovered now. I’m sure the army surgeons would say you’re ready to return to duty.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: So, you'd like me to leave?

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I didn’t say that.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Surely not, you’re too polite a lady to be so blunt about it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am as blunt as I need to be, Corporal McBurney. Since you brought it up, I will tell you that I think your leg is healed enough to leave by the end of this week.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: That’s in just a few days.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Yes, it is.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Where would I go?

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I'm afraid that is entirely your business where you go, Corporal. However I should think you might find columns of your troops on the main road to Richmond. He looks out.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Your garden should have continual care, you need a full- time gardener.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Perhaps, but I expect we’ll have to do without in these times. McBurney looks upset, fragile.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: It’s a pity isn’t it, that I couldn't have remained helpless. 55. Miss Martha stares at him for a moment, and then picks up skirts and leaves, disappearing into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy lies on a sofa crying. Alicia, and Emily crowd around her.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I don’t know exactly, but she asked him to leave.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: We will have to make things so pleasant for him that he won't even consider leaving us, until we decide of course, that it’s time for him to go.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: We might suggest to Miss Martha that it would be nice if Corporal McBurney could join us at the table for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Yes, he must get lonely eating alone in his room.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: We should show him some real Southern hospitality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane cuts some wild flowers in a field, making a small bouquet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwina joins McBurney by the window, alone in his room.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I’ve missed being near you.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: Have you? She looks down shyly.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: You have no idea how lovely you are. Edwina’s stiff manner crumbles.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Miss Farnsworth suggested it’s time for me to be on my way.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to leave.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to leave you, Edwina. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: Please... don’t ever say that to me unless you mean it.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I do. I knew exactly how I felt about you from that first day I talked to you, but was afraid to say anything for fear you'd never let me near you again. I’m only telling you now because this may be my only chance. I realize I’m not good enough for you, Edwina.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: That’s not true.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I’m tired of this war, I want to see the West... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: If you can get to Richmond, my father can help you.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Come with me. He kisses her- it knocks the wind out of her. A KNOCK at the door interrupts them. Edwina, light-headed, stands up, smooths her skirt. Alicia and Jane enter.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Miss Martha invites you to dine with us, Corporal.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Thank you, that would be my great pleasure. Jane and Alicia curtsey innocently. Edwina rushes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a flurry of activity of girls rushing to their rooms. Amy passes Edwina.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Have you heard -- the Corporal is joining us for dinner tonight! Evidently Miss Martha was fearful she might have hurt his feelings by asking him to leave so she invited him to dine with us. Edwina watches her go, and rushes off herself. INT. GIRLS’ ROOM - EVENING Emily tightens the laces on Jane’s corset. Close up on ribbons in their hair.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Have you got it?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Almost. The SOUND of a dinner BELL ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alicia looks at herself in a mirror. She stares for a sec and then reaches up and pinches her cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the glow of candlelight, McBurney is surrounded by the ladies and girls of the Farnsworth school. They are all dressed up in their best. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The evening is festive, with chatter and the passing of b and platters of sweet potato pie, black-eyed peas and biscuits. They are all enjoying having a man at the table but Jane is still suspicious of the Northern enemy. A radiant Edwina wears a blue silk dress, that sits off h shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: That dress is very becoming on you, Miss Edwina.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: There might be other attractive shoulders here if we were all permitted to wear such dresses.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: It is not entirely suitable dress for a young ladies school, but we know that Miss Edwina is accustomed to town society with different views. I suggest we change the subject and that Miss Edwina might consider drawing her shawl to prevent any other speculation on the subject. Edwina demurely pulls her shawl over her shoulders as Ali watches. McBurney gives Edwina a little smile from across the tabl She smiles back at him.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: This is the finest meal I can remember.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Merci Beaucoup...Miss Alicia made the pie herself.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: I made apple pie.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: You don’t say? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alicia smiles, pleased with herself.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I picked the apples.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Delicious.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: Is that my recipe, Miss Alicia? Jane looks at Alicia. Alicia is coy to Edwina.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Why, yes it is. Edwina takes a bite, with a glance to Alicia.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: (to McBurney) We’re fortunate to have had enough water for our garden.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Yes, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls are chatting and Jane finishes playing “Concert B Minor” by Oskar Reiding on her violin for McBurney who nearby, listening appreciatively.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: That’s a beautiful song. Jane smiles, flattered. Alicia leans in to McBurney with baby-doll eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Isn't it? I’ve always thought it was rather romantic... He look at her like a wolf. Jane sits down at the harpsic and begins to play Stephen Foster’s “Virginia Belle”. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwina enters the room to see Alicia leaning by McBurney, flirtatiously chatting with him at the window. McBurney turns to see Edwina and makes his way over to he with his cane. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next to Edwina, he squeezes her hand reassuringly. He loo at her, as she avoids his stare. He leans in and speaks under his breath, as if it’s a tortured burden -- to be so close to her and not grab her

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: My love. She looks away, flustered. Alicia passes by and gives Edwina a snotty look like -- I the one he wants. Edwina looks to McBurney. He leans in, whispers to her under the music, she smiles they exchange whispered plans. Miss Martha appears. McBurney straightens himself and bows to Miss Martha.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: May I offer you a digestif, some brandy, Corporal?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Yes, ma’am. He nods to Edwina and sits down with Miss Martha, happy t partake.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: My father had quite a cellar in his day. The house was full of parties... People traveled from all over to come here.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: I'll bet it was splendid here, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: It was. There were elegant dinners and balls... carriages lined up, beautiful gowns and men in full dress... She smiles and lifts her glass as they sip brandy togethe (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: A toast to you, Miss Martha, you must be the bravest lady I’ve ever known. She's flattered.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Oh, all bravery is -- is doing what must be done at the time. Tell me, Corporal, do you think this war will be over soon?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Very soon, sooner than you Southerners are ready to admit.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: I know...

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: And you could use some help around here. A man’s help. He sips the brandy slowly and looks into her eyes. Miss Martha tilts her head in reflection. She looks up as the music ends, and sets down her glass.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Please gather for our evening prayers. Miss Martha starts the prayers, as the others gather arou in the candlelight. MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) Dear Lord, we ask for your protection over our school and all of the brave members of our army...

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: And may we ask to look out for our friend, Corporal McBurney, as he makes his way. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss Amy. Corporal McBurney’s stay with us has taught us all a very important lesson, that the enemy as an individual is not what we believed. Let us bow in silent meditation. The girls bow their heads. Alicia sneaks a look to McBurney. Amy looks at her, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwina passes McBurney and Miss Martha in the dark hallwa In the dim candlelight, Edwina and McBurney exchange a knowing look, and Edwina continues on. Miss Martha stops at her room. She and McBurney stand at doorway, as she holds a candelabra, facing him. Is he goi to join her? She looks at him, she is softer.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Well, good night, Corporal. You will need your rest. She touches his arm.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Yes, ma’am. He looks at her. The moment is filled with anticipation. Suddenly a door SLAMS above, and a girl calls out:

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Please! Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: AMY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m not doing anything! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Miss Martha calls up to them.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Girls! Quiet down. The moment is broken, McBurney looks at her. Miss Martha gives him a little curtsey. MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) Good night, Corporal.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Good night, ma’am. Thank you for your hospitality. Miss Martha goes up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. EDWINA’S ROOM - NIGHT Edwina washes her face carefully. CLOSE on her hands as she unfolds a garment folded in pap She holds up a Parisian lace-trimmed nightgown that looks like it’s never been worn. She carefully slips it on, and brushes her hair -- counti with each stroke, as she imagines herself as a bride.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: One, two, three, four, five, six, seven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small bottle of perfume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwina puts perfume behind her ears. Edwina leaves her door slightly ajar. She lies on her bed next to the glow of a candle, full of anticipation. We SEE the outline of her hair as she waits (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the SOUNDS of the house at night in almost silenc The battles seem to have moved on. We hear the sound of CICADAS. We hear some GIRLS say good-night in other rooms.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SECOND FLOOR BALCONY- NIGHT
dialogues.text: We see McBurney’s outline on the dark back balcony.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. EDWINA’S ROOM -NIGHT CLOSE on Edwina -- she hears a SOUND on the steps -- the CREAKS. We hear a few heavy STEPS come CLOSER -- and then pass. Barely breathing, Edwina lies for a few more beats, then up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwina, holding up a candlestick, carefully walks down th dark hall. We hear what sounds like muffled GIGGLES. Edwina in her nightgown makes her way closer to a room -- door barely ajar, a low LIGHT seeping out. It’s quiet now. Edwina wonders if she was imagining sound then she hears a CREAK and a LAUGH and moves forward. Edwina opens the door to find --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over a bare milky white ass, McBurney is in bed with Alic naked body on top of him. He’s grabbing her and clearly having a good time. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look up to see Edwina. Edwina steps back -- as McBur jumps up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Edwina!

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: No --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McBurney, smiling with assurance, moves toward Edwina, as backs up in shock. He reaches for her.

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: Dear Edwina -- She backs up towards the stairs, he reaches for her. She pushes him away, as she drops the candle and SCREAMS. In the darkness, we hear McBurney tumbles down the stairs calling out in agony. Edwina crumples to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martha rushes out, followed by the other girls, all nightgowns. They crowd around to see -- McBurney lying unconscious at bottom of the stairs in the darkness. Miss Martha takes a lamp, and holds it up. We see blood pooling around McBurney, his leg contorted. Amy, looking through the stair banister, cries.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Is he dead?! Miss Martha leans in to check his pulse.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: No, but we have to stop the bleeding. Edwina joins them at the bottom of the stairs, her tear- stained face in shock. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS MARTHA (CONT’D) What has happened?!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, Miss Martha! Edwina is in shock and can’t explain herself.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Is he going to die?!

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: (urgent) Get some rags! Alicia comes down the stairs, not seeing the severity of

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: I was so shaken I could hardly bring myself to leave my room. No one pays attention, Miss Martha rushes to make a tourniquet. She is much less gentle than on his arrival.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was terrible the way he rushed in, I was frightened half to death, and then Edwina came out and began fighting with him. Emily brings a bowl of water. Amy has some old cloth.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: We have to get him to the table. Help me move him. Marie comes to her side. Jane recoils, the girls are scar to get closer.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Is he going to be alright?

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Be quite, and help. The girls help to pick him up.  68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women gather around, blocking McBurney, who lies on t dining table. A lamp lights the table from the mantle. We SEE their backs as they look at McBurney. Jane turns to us in horror for what she sees. Amy covers mouth, as Emily ushers them away.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: We may have to remove it. Close on McBurney’s unconscious face.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: What?! No! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alicia calls down as she descends the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is there anything I can do? She enters the dining room. They ignore her. Miss Martha focuses on the patient.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was so shocked and shaken, I could hardly bring myself to leave my room.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Is that so, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Yes, I was asleep, when he came upstairs. Amy brings water.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Were you indeed?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: It was terrible the way he rushed in, I was frightened half to death.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: What did he want?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: How should I know?

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Be quiet, all of you.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Nothing happened, I swear! Alicia starts sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: (firmly) Go to your room. Alicia sulks off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martha goes back to the table. The girls gather arou blocking the gruesomeness of his injury. Amy squeezes Emily’s hand. Edwina puts a cold compress on McBurney’s forehead. He se to wake up for a moment in a daze.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: MCBURNEY
dialogues.text: (mutters) I‘1l still be leaving.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: His leg is broken badly this time. I can’t repair it, I’m not a surgeon.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh dear lord!

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Quiet!

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: What will you do?!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Don’t distract her! The girls squabble.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA
dialogues.text: Go to your rooms! Miss Martha steps aside, as the girls scurry off in tears McBurney lies unconscious on the table. Miss Martha turns Edwina at the mantle.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MARTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have to amputate. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martha is stone-faced.

dialogues.speaker: EDWINA
dialogues.text: What?! NO! Miss Martha snaps at her.
